author: FlameoHotman-_-
body:
This has to be an unpopular opinion...and for the record, I distrust the CCP as much as the next person, but these crackdowns may not be entirely bad. Let's look at some examples:

\- So in this case, Didi's operation got suspended because "Didi had illegally collected users' personal data."

\- Alibaba got fined because of monopolistic practices.

\- Ant Group's IPO got slashed because the CCP wanted to regulate Ant Group like an actual bank.

To be honest, these sound pretty reasonable to me. Facebook was in trouble for collecting data without content too. Remember the whole Cambridge Analytica scandal? But now everyone is hot for FB stocks.

Microsoft has been fined millions by the EU for monopolistic practices as well. But everyone loves Microsoft stocks nonetheless. 

And as to Ant Group, they are a massive financial service company that can offer customers credit. How come they don't get to be regulated like a bank? My point is that these actions make sense and good regulations is beneficial for investors too in the long run.

author: Pdicky69
body:
$NET is on a fundamental basis is over valued. They expect rev to be $500M+ this year but they trade at $33B. It’s been on of my biggest picked winners. 

Here is a quick breakdown of what the popular services they offer, highly scaleable and a HUGE TAM.

https://www.freelancer.com/articles/web-development/cloudflare

However I sold off at $75, $85 levels due to price action getting ahead of the fundamental business. I’ve exited about 50% of my position. I still have 200 shares because I believe, it could do some long term stuff well and be a $100B company. But I can’t allocate so much of my portfolio in this company vs a FB/AMZN/GOOG (where I get growth, balance sheet safety, and moat)

From here, if you want to get in on the action. You have to believe they do a few things…
1) surprise HEAVILY on revenue growth and forward guidance
2) grow more into their cyber security suite of tools beyond just basic stuff like their widely used DDOS prevention (a ton of websites use them for this) and firewall 
3) Content delivery network investment trend continues and profit margins aren’t competed away with bigger boys entering the game (ie GOOG, MSFT, AMZN)
4) website speeds overwhelmingly determine ranking on google and mobile searches

Cloudflare and Fastly are the two more popular services for websites and apps to use as they offer ease of use to speed up website access for users and support to prevent website downtime. Folks have frequently complimented on how easy cloudflare is to use.

Microsoft in the 1990s was the most valuable company in the world switching spots with GE, it is currently the only company that was in the top 10 list in 1990 and is currently still top 10 right now (at #2 spot behind apple). It was the #1 company by marketcap in 2019 and march 2020.

It faces less regulatory risk than tech giants competitors allowing for easy acquisitions thanks to its stellar balance sheet.

author: harrison_wintergreen
body:
ELI5: 

- Burry believes (as he wrote): "passive investing has removed price discovery from the equity markets". https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-04/michael-burry-explains-why-index-funds-are-like-subprime-cdos

- price discovery is the process of estimating a reasonable fair value for a stock. 

- because relatively few people are buying/selling stocks based on their fair value, prices for stocks are often being determined mainly by cash-flows. see Tesla or dogecoin for examples. Tesla sells under 1% all vehicles worldwide but is somehow worth *more than all the other carmakers combined* because lots of people were buying Tesla stock and not because of any financial status of Tesla. dogecoin started LITERALLY as a joke but somehow was more valuable than companies like Ford Motors only because a ton of cash flowed into Dogecoin. this is all sheer insanity by traditional stock valuation guidelines. asset bubbles are nothing new, but Burry believes it's being exacerbated by passive investing. 

- Burry believes this situation of prices being based on cash flows is similar to what happened in the housing bubble, when multi-zillion Collateralized Debt Obligations (CDOs) were being priced not by a reasonable estimate of their fair value but by cash-flows. 

- when flows reverse and lots of people want out of index funds, it will get ugly because so many stocks are linked/benchmarked to major stock indexes *including lower volume stocks*. consider VTI: the top holdings (Apple, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson) might have a billion shares in total and hundreds of millions of dollars trading each day. but the smallest company stocks might have only a few million shares and a few million dollars trading each day. if too many people want to sell all at the same time, it will drive prices down sharply because these stocks are so often sold as a bundle/unit. as Burry puts it: "The theater keeps getting more crowded, but the exit door is the same as it always was"

>since the guy predicted 2007-2008 crash.

he also predicted the dot-com bubble.

author: zxc123zxc123
body:
Hi. I'm from the Intel side! I think AMD side shouldn't worry too much about INTC. It's a big old ship that's getting bombarded from all sides. The fact that it's a big ship means it's changes will take time. I'm giving Gelsinger a chance to right the ship, but it will take a long while to undo BSwan's bad moves, get the right people, develop the chips, and catch up to AMD. 

A plus side for everyone is that the semi-space is a growing area with electronification, digitization, and "5G-cloudification" of everything along with the increasing importance of AI & tech in business and government. Semis are so important in fact, that at this point US Gov should really be looking at INTC/NVD/TI more like they did Ford/GM 100 years ago: as a strategic industrial/military resource. 

Real threat to AMD isn't INTC. INTC was the big market share holder in the past and isn't likely gaining any ground any time soon. What AMD and all the trad chip manufacturers should fear is FAAAM & BAT. Apple has started designing it's own chips. They aren't going back to using outsourced chips. If history says anything it's that Apple will continue to cut others out as they continue to in-house their chips for their entire lineup while improving their chips just like how they kept improving their computers, just like how the iphone kept improving until NOK/MOT were beat, just like how a good chunk of the watch market is Apple watches, just like how Ipads have taken away from of the laptop space, just like how Apple TV keeps chipping away at cable, just like how the app store and Apple's eco system keeps growing, etcetcetc. There is nothing AMD/NVD/INTC can do to stop Apple. And Apple is just the first. MSFT also doing the same. Google, Facebook, and Amazon might follow suit. China's Tencent and Alibaba will likely copy what the US companies do as soon as Pooh Bear gets done man handling them.

author: YourInnate
body:
It's a matter of perspective and big picture stuff. If you bough a SPY leap the day before the market crashed last year from covid, and bought 100 shares the day before the crash in covid, the LEAP would be worth more today.

2-5% a month seems super low, but options are a grind. When in doubt, zoom out. 2-5% a month is 25-60% a year. Consider the indexes historically return 10%, doubling that on your bad years and quintupling it on your good years seems like a good trade.

Another note, this past year has been a historic bull run/recovery for most of the stock market. You can't compare throwing money into microsoft or google and watching it appreciate vs selling options on the same underlying. Likewise, if you had been selling RIOT/MARA puts the first 4 months of the year, you could've been making 10% a week. 

Everything in the market is perspective. If you think 2-5% a month is too slow/boring... You might consider roulette.

author: Nosefuroughtto
body:
I find it odd to consider Amazon like Standard Oil. SO derived it’s monopolistic power through acquisitions of rival refineries and distributors; purely horizontal integration, followed by outright price fixing.

Amazon is absolutely massive, but the growth method and diversity of markets they participate in distinguishes them from old trust oriented monopolies. I’m terms of AWS, the majority of growth was organic, and would not have ran afoul of antitrust law back in its hay day, such as when US v. Aluminum Co. of America was prevailing law.

An attempt to break up Amazon by business segment would probably fail due to the shift since the 70’s from Per Se Antitrust violations to the Rule of Reason. They aren’t dominating any given sector to the point that a court could likely prove anti-consumer behavior, which has increasingly become the prime factor.

Online shopping has a fairly rich market with Walmart, Home Depot, Best Buy, wayfair, etc.; physical stores obviously have Walmart and target being dominant; subscription services are still beaten by Netflix and Google, with Disney catching up fast; AWS competes with Oracle, Microsoft snd Google.

Overall I think the justifications for breaking up Amazon are weak in light of the method of growth, the fact that they aren’t shutting out competitors in any given industry right now, and our much more consumer viewpoint focus on antitrust enforcement.

>Good thing you can share your wisdom then, oh eternal oracle of the market.

Hmmm. I'm don't recall trying to predict when the market will crash and I post quite a bit, when I'm qualified to do so. My advice this time was making users aware of how bad this post was and how illiterates most this sub is. 

>Surely you know more then Dalio, what books have you written?

L. Ron Hubbard and Cosby wrote books too. That's a pretty low bar. 

>Gold is a old-school store of value by definition and as we saw in 2020 (amongst others) a great asset during times of uncertainty and crashes. Buy it during calm times, sell during fearful times.

Yeah, that's not accurate. Gold is not a hedge, its a portfolio diversifier. It's market correlation is 0.02, which is an unattached, positive number...not the large negative correlation you would hope for from a hedge. It did absolutely nothing during the dot-com bubble and probably hurt most investors that held during 2020.

author: CodeMaitre
body:
ORCL One Year and 6 Month Chart - [https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg](https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg)

It has pretty much made its move, you'd be buying in the "sell" area statistically. You're correct, the buy zone is  always below regression trend (average) line in the middle, so you'd want to snag it if it goes back down to 75-80. Although its true downward potential is the blue -1 deviation line, so 70-73. Deviations change a little bit day to day as more price data is added but right now you'd be buying into an uptrend which is not very safe. You'd basically be betting to get the cherry on top running up to +1 deviations at 88-91.

author: Toys_R_Them
body:
Most of the new growth has been in tech, and tech rarely pays dividends, outside of some stalwarts like MSFT and ORCL.

A lot of those dividend payers are energy companies and REITs, who also underperformed for various pandemic-related reasons.

A portfolio that high in dividends is typically recommended for older people, who need current income and downside protection in case of economic swings, and could care less about potential growth of their portfolio decades from now.

author: OfficialTestikills
body:
I personally invest heavily in Web3 crypto's and crypto projects that help run and keep these crypto's decentralised. 

What's a web3 crypto? These aren't to be confused with junk like Bitcoin that thinks it is a store of value or will become the new financial system, web3 crypto is literally creating the next stage in internet where you don't need to worry about your companies information / personal information / classified documents being stored on a server that is owned and managed by other companies. Web3 splits this up between 100's of validators that all talk to each other and keep this decentralised and secure from attacks. 

There's also ones creating the future of finance. No longer do you need to get bent over by huge interest rates and banks fucking people over whenever they feel like it. DEFI is run by liquidity pools, people like you and I who store our money with the service and as a result get a percentage of the interest rates. These rates always remain low and competitive and go to the people rather than the big banks.

Then you have oracles that power the decentralisation. Oracles gain info from many sources and feed it to the protocol to offer decentralised information. For easy laymans terms, if I wanted a weather oracle, it would gather weather data from 1000's weather stations and news outlets, work out the average forecast and feed that to my protocol. This means my protocol is giving the users the most accurate non-biased information. Just as a high-level. 

So how do you make money from this? Well, let's look at Ethereum just as an example. Every single protect that runs on Ethereum has to pay "gas" fees on each transaction, this is paid in Ethereum. Ethereum already has 1000's of applications including VISA and MasterCard that constantly have a demand for Ethereum in order to operate and pay these gas fees. You as the investor holds the Ethereum they need and this creates supply and demand. Additionally, each time a company pays their gas fees, the gas is "burnt" (meaning Ethereum used to pay for the transaction is burnt) creating deflation. 

Ethereum is just one project, and not one that I personally even invest in that much, but it's one that I'm sure most people have heard of.   
If you want to look at getting some crypto while it's currently on a low and has huge potentially to be the future of a new decentralised internet feel free to use my exchange code. author: Modja
body:
I worked sales in payments for four years. A large international payments company. Direct competitor to Paysafe in all respects except we were more restrained on gambling.

Paysafe make money, in large part, by charging merchants for a fee per card transaction. This is known as merchant acquiring. (Yes, the term "acquiring" is a little odd here, but keep following)

This fee is subject to many variables, including interchange fees charged to Paysafe by the card scheme (Visa/MC), as well as competition. Acquirers historically were subsidaries of banks - Chase Paymentech are examples of one that still is - JPM, in this case.

 As fees are usually taken before income is paid to the merchant (else invoiced payable within 30 days), it means bank-linked acquirers can significantly reduce their txn fee (and thus increase the topline) for merchants as an incentive they want to upsell more profitable products like loans to. I have worked in the industry and seen it time and again. One large international merchant even got free acquiring, they were that good a customer of the bank's other services. I even worked personally in combo with a bank on a deal of such a type.

Whilst I appreciate that gambling companies are higher risk and some acquirers won't touch them...the barrier to entry is just the acquiring price and the willingness of a competitor to pant-drop. And they do.

Plus I interviewed at Paysafe once. UK office, pre-Covid. There wasn't any buzz, any excitement. It seemes boring and uninspired. Granted, its a subsidary office.

I hold no position on this stock and I am not planning to. Nor am I looking to shit all over the stock per se. Just cautious advice from personal experience.

author: Modja
body:
I worked sales in payments for four years. A large international payments company. Direct competitor to Paysafe in all respects except we were more restrained on gambling.

Paysafe make money, in large part, by charging merchants for a fee per card transaction. This is known as merchant acquiring. (Yes, the term "acquiring" is a little odd here, but keep following)

This fee is subject to many variables, including interchange fees charged to Paysafe by the card scheme (Visa/MC), as well as competition. Acquirers historically were subsidaries of banks - Chase Paymentech are examples of one that still is - JPM, in this case.

 As fees are usually taken before income is paid to the merchant (else invoiced payable within 30 days), it means bank-linked acquirers can significantly reduce their txn fee (and thus increase the topline) for merchants as an incentive they want to upsell more profitable products like loans to. I have worked in the industry and seen it time and again. One large international merchant even got free acquiring, they were that good a customer of the bank's other services. I even worked personally in combo with a bank on a deal of such a type.

Whilst I appreciate that gambling companies are higher risk and some acquirers won't touch them...the barrier to entry is just the acquiring price and the willingness of a competitor to pant-drop. And they do.

Plus I interviewed at Paysafe once. UK office, pre-Covid. There wasn't any buzz, any excitement. It seemes boring and uninspired. Granted, its a subsidary office.

I hold no position on this stock and I am not planning to. Nor am I looking to shit all over the stock per se. Just cautious advice from personal experience.

author: SPYfuncoupons
body:
You need to learn them even more. Naked calls OTM are risky. there isn’t much strategy there. Don’t play earnings. Don’t hop into a trade unless you are guaranteed to win that trade. Cheap calls generally aren’t worth it. You should also base your call on a lot more data. I only trade SPY gaps and LEAPS on some stocks. When SPY goes straight down vertically that money comes right back and it goes straight back up vertically within a few days. I buy an ITM call within a few days of the decline. 19/20 trades profited from that. 
For LEAPS you have to understand Theta and time decay more, and go far far ITM which means the price of the call will be extremely expensive, but they are worth it in my opinion. I bought a $200 strike Visa call expiring in a year, when Visa was at $234 a share. it’s now at $238 a share and the call is up 4% or so. the contract cost $4,000 but I lose a dollar (-0.01 x 100 shares) per day to time decay if the stock doesn’t move, which is nothing. I gain $79-80 or so every dollar the stock moves up. I only discovered these methods after 2 years of losing in options, and now I’m winning

author: redditsuaku
body:
with options, you're generally concerned with two things, the direction of the underlying (long v short) and volatility to increase or decrease. option values are directly correlated to volatility. higher volatility = higher option premiums.

while both buying call and writing puts are long positions, they are opposite in relation to volatility. buying a call means you pay for the option premium and expect volatility to increase. when you write a put, you are selling the premium and expecting the volatility to decrease.

theta decay comes into play as well which decreases an option's premium over time. thus selling options tend to be more probably wins vs. buying them. also why selling options needs more capital than buying 'em.

author: redtexture
body:
Short holders of options have no control over assignment. 
You cannot prevent this lack of control.  
It can happen any time.  

Generally, early exercise and assignment is fairly uncommon, except for dividend arbitrage,    
and high implied volatility stocks  (which are not suitable for Iron Condors or Iron Butterflies anyhow).

author: ghostwriter85
body:
I'm not interested in rental property so grain of salt.          

I would say it really depends on your clients overall financial picture and goals.       

From a pure equity position I'm still somewhat bullish on real estate unless the property is in a place that has seen a tremendous Covid boost (small mountain towns out west) that could theoretically revert back to baselines over time as restrictions ease and people remember why they liked living in those cities to begin with (or continue to grow... who knows).       

From an immediate income perspective, there are certainly easier options.  Once the access to low cost leverage is gone (loan paid off) simply buying quality REITs might provide a similar level of after expense income in the same sector (unless your client places a very low value on their time).  Granted income yields are low just about everywhere.                      

As an interest rate hedge it might be worth it in the longer term to hold if a sufficient amount of leverage is still held.  Yes a spike in rates might hurt the theoretical equity position but that should, in theory at least, balance against the inflated currency.                         

Anyways, if your client is purely interested in income why not put together an alternative income proposal that matches their timeline and risk profile?  You sell at U, pay V taxes, invest in W, see X income, free up Y hours, and avoid risks Z.

author: BigBrianBrand
body:
1. 3-5x in terms of total returns assuming the top 10 market caps continue to outperform the bottom 490 companies over the next decade (this is too optimistic admittedly. But compound growth is killer if the business continues to rapidly expand year over year. It would also make up more of the S&P as well though to be fair, which favors index investing in terms of optimal risk-reward). 

2. OP was talking about the top 10 companies by market cap which is all big tech other than Johnson & Johnson, and Berkshire Hathaway. They named Microsoft, Apple, and Visa off-hand. 

3. I Hate this crystal ball argument, of course the future is impossible to 100% predict. That’s why you pick financially healthy companies with great growth prospects and economic moats. You invest in companies that give you the highest probability of outperforming the market. It’s obvious a company like Microsoft is likely going to outperform a mid-cap company such as Texas Roadhouse. Just as how I can’t guarantee I won’t be alive tomorrow. But I have a higher chance of living if I pay attention while driving a car vs texting while driving. 

4. You don’t just invest in one company. You invest in a handful of individual stocks that you expect to have a high probability of beating the market (Buffet and Lynch recommend 7-15 roughly). People should only do this if they know what they are doing. The average person should stick to indexes if they are not willing to do the research of course. 

I’m not disagreeing with index investing as much as I want to highlight that beating the market isn’t this absurdly, low probability phenomenon people want to believe that it is. OP has the right premise for a high probabilistic chance to beat the market.

author: Lord_of_Barad_Dur
body:
Bud. You’re throwing money at companies almost no one has heard of. Use Ben Graham’s equation. It balances returns in dividend yield with returns in increase in value. Take GEVO, for instance:

V= [EPS * (8.5+2g) * 4.4]/ Y

EPS= earnings per share
g=projected 10 year growth
4.4= dividend yield of AAA corporate bonds in 1962
Y= dividend yield of AAA corporate bonds today (risk-free earnings yield)
GEVO’s looks like this:

V= [0.41 * (8.5-31.72) * 4.4]/2.6 = 16.1%

This means GEVO is 16.1% overvalued.

Just take this equation, and apply it to any stock. It tends to work better than market average in the long-term. Most important, however, is DON’T GET STOCKS FROM WALL STREET BETS. THERE ARE NOW A BUNCH OF BOTS THERE JUST POSTING ABOUT STOCKS SO THEY CAN OFFLOAD THEM.

author: MVST_100_OR_BUST
body:
Just to be open and because I care more about y'all more than myself or Vogel I do want to mention that there has been a change in the lockup. Not good or bad just changed.

It's been all over the place since last year between Vogel and Wu. But this is the final iteration it seems.

The last iteration was
Wu: 25% locked for 1 year unless above $15 for 20 days. 75% two year locked 

Other Microvast shareholders: 6 months

Vogel/Tuscan: 
50% is locked for 1 year, unless it trades above $12.50 for 20 days. The other 50% is locked for 2 years.



**Now it is**
Wu: 25% locked for 1 year unless above $15 for 20 days. 75% two year locked. (Yes unchanged)

Other Microvast shareholders: 6 months

Vogel/Tuscan:
**READ THIS CAREFULLY**
 
Of 75% of shares, 67% of the shares are locked for 1 year unless above $12.50 for 20 days. The other 33% is locked for 1 year regardless of price. 

Of the other 25% of shares, 50% is locked for 1 year unless it trades over $12 for 20 days. The other 50% is locked for 1 year unless it trades over 15. However he will lose his shares if none of these conditions are met.

These lockups are fairly similar (e.g 67% of 75% is 50%). I don't know if he's fucking with me or I'm just stupid). In summarize it's leaning more positive in my opinion that Vogel got himself a poor man's "FDs" and is either bullish or likes to gamble. Can slightly sell more now if it goes up, but will forfeit ownership to them for $0 if it doesn't.

I've used it. Very good fees, good platform and pretty darn quick. It's up there with Remitly for me.

My ranking is:

author: Doctor_Profits
body: After I graduated college in 1998, I moved to a city and got a job for a company that had a ESPP.  The plan was that on the last day of each quarter, I could buy FDC stock at a 15% discount based on the stock price on the 1st day of the quarter, or the last day of the quarter, whichever was lower.  Over several years I accumulated almost 1000 shares of FDC.  8 years after I started working there, they spun off WU stock (which I sold soon after) and a few months after that they were bought by a private equity company and taken private.
